Award.AwardTitle: Significance of Newly Discovered Subduction Complex, Including Partially Serpentinized Mantle Peridotite, Southwest Arizona
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Late Cretaceous to early Paleogene Pelona, Orocopia, and Rand Schists of southern California and southwest Arizona represent an extensive subduction complex underplated beneath the continental crust of southwest North America during low-angle northeastward subduction, coeval with the Laramide orogeny. Several important aspects of the low-angle subduction process are poorly understood, mainly because only a small fraction of the subducted schist is exposed at the surface. The field of schists available for study was significantly widened in 2012, when we discovered an additional exposure of Orocopia Schist unusually far inland--at Cemetery Ridge, 90 kilometers west of the outskirts of greater Phoenix.

Determination of uranium-lead detrital-zircon ages and argon-argon metamorphic ages for the schist at Cemetery Ridge will reveal whether the Pelona, Orocopia, and Rand Schists decreases in age to the southeast, parallel to the former subduction margin; or to the northeast, perpendicular to the former margin. Resolution of this question will allow a choice between two widely discussed tectonic models: progressive inboard subduction erosion or migration of an aseismic ridge parallel to the subduction trench. Furthermore, field and Argon-Argon study of exhumation faults at Cemetery Ridge will contribute to understanding of processes whereby deeply subducted rocks are returned to the upper crust and surface.

Unexpectedly, the Orocopia Schist at Cemetery Ridge includes numerous blocks and fragments of oceanic or continental-margin mantle peridotite, chiefly serpentinized dunite and partially serpentinized harzburgite to olivine orthopyroxenite. Much of the peridotite is converted to actinolite-rich metasomatic rocks, but some contains abundant orthopyroxene and a little relict olivine. The well-preserved ultramafic rocks and minerals at Cemetery Ridge are unique in the Pelona, Orocopia, and Rand Schists, and their presence so far inland is remarkable. We will use field, petrographic, geochemical, and electron microprobe techniques to determine the origin of the peridotite, and how it was incorporated into and transported with the Orocopia Schist. In particular, we want to know whether it more closely resembles abyssal or mantle-wedge (suprasubduction) peridotite. Study of metasomatized peridotite at Cemetery Ridge will reveal details of chemical interactions between crustally derived (meta)sedimentary rocks and mantle peridotite within a low-angle subduction complex.

This project has two major goals. First, we will determine the ages of rocks in and processes that formed the subduction complex at Cemetery Ridge; these ages are fundamental to understanding its origin. Second, we will study the character and origin of the remarkable peridotites at Cemetery Ridge, in order to determine how these oceanic rocks were transported so far inland. Our project will contribute to knowledge of mechanisms of low-angle subduction in southwest North America. In particular, low-angle subduction is intimately related to formation of the Rocky Mountains, which dominate the natural and human geography of much of the American West. More generally, study of the subduction complex exposed on-land in southern California and southwest Arizona will complement evidence from marine geology and geophysics and further understanding of subduction on a global scale. In addition to the scientific goals of the research, this project is contributing to the training of undergraduate students from Iowa State University in all aspects of the research, including field and laboratory work, as well as presenting the results of the research at professional society meetings. Results of the research will also be incorporated into a workshop for middle and high school students on the tectonics of western North America that will be taught at the University of Iowa's geology field station in Wyoming. The project involves collaboration with UCSC and Stanford for geochemical and isotopic analyses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Subduction is a shallow phase or aspect of a global thermal convection system that encompasses the outer two-thirds of the mass of the solid Earth. Subduction takes place along active continental margins where oceanic crust and upper mantle are returned to or recycled into the deeper mantle. Detailed understanding of subduction processes is essential for several human concerns, notably landscape evolution, geologic hazards, and mineral resources. Most subduction zones are moderately inclined but, in a few places, such as the Aleutian Islands and parts of the Andes, the subduction zone has unusually low inclination. Low-angle subduction zones are difficult to study directly, because subducted material becomes hidden far beneath the continental margin. An important exception is found in southern California and southwest Arizona. Here deeply subducted rocks have locally been returned to the surface by later faulting and erosion, making this one of the best regions in the world to study products and processes of low-angle subduction. Since the 1970s, geologists have assumed that all exposures of this subduction complex were known. In 2012 we discovered an additional exposure of subducted rocks unusually far inland—at Cemetery Ridge, 90 km west of the outskirts of greater Phoenix. Unexpectedly, these rocks include numerous blocks and fragments of several types of peridotite (magnesium-rich, silica-poor igneous rock), characteristic of oceanic or continental-margin upper mantle. Our work at Cemetery Ridge has resulted in publication of three papers in peer-reviewed scientific journals or books, as well as several abstracts of research still in progress.

The oceanic peridotite at Cemetery Ridge is strikingly out-of-place, as it is entirely surrounded by quintessentially continental rocks. Our first paper (2015) describes our discovery of the remarkable peridotite at Cemetery Ridge, documents its geologic setting and petrologic characteristics, and reaches the provisional conclusion that the peridotite was detached from the upper plate (“hanging wall”) of the subduction zone. In our tentative hypothesis, the peridotite blocks at Cemetery Ridge were derived from or related to continental-margin oceanic terranes now widely exposed in the California Coast Ranges. This finding emphasizes the importance of tectonic erosion in low-angle subduction zones.

The episode of low-angle subduction that formed the rocks at Cemetery Ridge apparently affected the geology of much of western North America. It led to the cessation of volcanic activity in the Sierra Nevada of California, uplift of the Rocky Mountains, and reorganization of river systems throughout the West. To help understand the relationships between these different phenomena we conducted dating of the mineral zircon in metamorphosed sandstones at Cemetery Ridge. Most of the zircon grains are dominantly relics from the original sands that were carried under North America by low-angle subduction. The ages of this primary zircon indicate that the sands were derived by erosion within various areas of southern California and southwestern Arizona. Many of the zircon grains also show secondary growth during low-angle subduction. This metamorphic zircon indicates that subduction occurred approximately 70-65 million years ago, coincident with the initial growth of the Rocky Mountains. This work is described in the second paper stemming from this project, published in 2017.

Serpentinization is the common process whereby high-temperature, igneous, anhydrous minerals in peridotite react with seawater, at low temperature, to form the hydrous mineral serpentine, and the metamorphic rock serpentinite. The peridotite at Cemetery Ridge evidently was serpentinized in its original oceanic setting, not at its present location in southwest Arizona. Our third paper (2018) documents in detail some ten unusual serpentinization-related metallic minerals, containing iron, nickel, and cobalt, in the Cemetery Ridge peridotite. These minerals were analyzed by scanning electron microscope and electron microprobe. Seven of the minerals are sulfides, two are arsenides, and one an iron-nickel alloy. They attest to the reduced (non-oxidized) conditions typical of serpentinization. Five minerals are new for Arizona, where serpentinite is rare and nickel and cobalt deposits unknown. In our paper we compare the metallic minerals in the Cemetery Ridge peridotite to those in similar rocks in such places at the California and Oregon Coast Ranges and Mid-Atlantic Ridge. Presence of these metallic minerals emphasizes the uniqueness of the tectonic setting of the subducted peridotite at Cemetery Ridge and enhances the special status of the subduction-zone rocks exposed there.
